intro: Centaurea thessala subsp. thessala, commonly known as the Thessalian cornflower, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of Greece. It belongs to the Asteraceae family and is characterized by its striking blue to purple flowers that bloom in summer. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with lance-shaped leaves that are covered in fine hairs. Its flowering heads are composed of both ray and disk florets, typical of the genus Centaurea. This subspecies is often found in rocky soils and open habitats, where it thrives in full sun.
